div.div: I think the error handling logic here is printing warning log and returning vm.ctx.none , so I think maybe error propagating can not be used here. I'm trying to find good way to reduce indents, how about one? let last = match envar.split('.').last() { Some(last) => last, (25 more lines were trimmed)

Failing: sindresorhus/eslint-plugin-unicorn/runs/7158388862?check_suite_focus=true I'm trying to resolve this issue, but I'm not sure how to handle this. CI failed because run-rules-on-codebase test include prefer-error-cause rule when checking intergration/test.mjs file. But when I added eslint-disable comment on the intergration/test.mjs 's failed lines, it cause lint error due to eslint can not find prefer-error-cause rule.

I think this is resolved now if I understand correctly. I replaced existing getMatchingAncestorOfType call with getCatchBlock for resolving (1). And I used esquery in the getCatchBlock for implementing for checking if the function is {then, catch} 's argument (2). And getCatchBlock return undefined if the throw statement is in the function to avoid existing wrong fix. (Fixing throw statement in the function foo in your example code)
Commented on #24 Expose all timeout options (custom `message`, `customTimers`)

@fregante I appreciate you pointing them out. I agree with all the points you made. I should have been look into the code after the p-timeout API change although there are also unrelated some mistakes.
Commented on #3979 Fix `PyFloat::py_new` always returning new float object issue

We need to move the exact float type check into PyNumber::float and return its payload with ref. Please refer to what payload_if_exact return and use into_ref ðŸ˜Š
number::float is not called when the argument is math.nan because try_float_opt early returned in this line. So I tried to edit try_float_opt instead like below, but it seems it is not working as expected. ( id(float(math.nan)) prints different oid each time) pub fn try_float_opt(&self, vm: &VirtualMachine) -> PyResult>> { let value = if let Some(float) = self.payload_if_exact::(vm) { (17 more lines were trimmed) I guess this is because below line returned new float instance instead of existing one. https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/blob/main/vm/src/builtins/float.rs#L152-L154 So, I think maybe we need to update the py_new function somehow.
Commented on #3979 Fix `PyFloat::py_new` always returning new float object issue

We need to move the exact float type check into PyNumber::float and return its payload with ref. Please refer to what payload_if_exact return and use into_ref ðŸ˜Š
number::float is not called when the argument is math.nan because try_float_opt early returned in this line. So I tried to edit try_float_opt instead like below, but it seems it is not working as expected. ( id(float(math.nan)) prints different oid each time) pub fn try_float_opt(&self, vm: &VirtualMachine) -> PyResult>> { let value = if let Some(float) = self.payload_if_exact::(vm) { (17 more lines were trimmed) I guess this is because below line returned new float instance instead of existing one. https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/blob/main/vm/src/builtins/float.rs#L152-L154 So, I think maybe we need to update the py_new function somehow.
Commented on #3978 `PyFloat::py_new` always return new float object even if the argument's oid is same.

I think returning same object when argument oid is same itself does not matter.. In cpython, unlike passing math.nan , >>> a = float('nan') >>> b = float('nan') (2 more lines were trimmed) I guess 'nan''s oid is same with the two line, but because 'nan' is not exact float type, a is b is false
